content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun and quick to solve
You should probably explain clearly how 12-hour clock works (specifically the part where there is no 00:xx which can be really confusing if you're from a country that uses sane clocks).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun to solve clash.
In my opinion it would be better to exclude minutes less than 10.
Some languages don't have precision formatter like in Python, therefore it brings a huge advantage against other languages in shortest mode

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: a nice clash to do (with the least character would be the most relevant I think!)

I like this challenge but I agree it may be too hard to spot that you are talking about clock times? Maybe better as a speed challenge? Or even as a code golf? I don't think it's too hard to solve in 5 mins though as you could just brute force it with 2 loops?

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: nice and original easy puzzle but not relevant for clash of code
too hard to solve in less than 5min, hard to understand what you are waiting for, after reading your solution
very hard (or impossible) to solve in less than 15min in reverse mode
Please give at least one example in your statements and publish it as an easy puzzle

I completely disagree; I think it's totally solvable in reverse mode, and very easily solvable in under 1 minute. I'm not certain what you mean by "hard to understand what you are waiting for, after reading your solution", so I'd love some clarification. Lastly, this puzzle is far too simple to be classed as an easy puzzle.

Thanks for the comment! I've included the fastest, shortest and reverse modes for this challenge. Given the examples I think it's plain to see that the output is a 12-hr clock format since it ranges from H:00 to H:59. I think you're talking just about reverse mode here since the other two modes you suggested are already part of this challenge; how much easier should it be? I really do not think this is difficult to figure out, especially given some of the reverse challenges I have encountered.

Thanks for your input! Isn't the point of shortest to find the best suitable solution? In my opinion this includes the right languages, because nobody is beating perl/bash/etc to begin with in these types of challenges.

After a second reading now i understand what you are waiting for.. your statements are not clear enough in my opinion, please disable reverse mode and take into consideration the Andriamanitra's comment and i will change my vote !
